source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: The remarkably low hydrogen uptake for Zr-2.5Nb compared with Zircaloy-2 is clearly evident. After about 3500 effective full power days, hydriding of Zr-2.5Nb is only 2 to 4% of that measured for Zircaloy-2.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: Low hydrogen uptake during corrosion has generally been a characteristic of dilute zirconiumniobium alloys

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: For Zircaloy-2, the percentage uptake increases during oxidation and becomes reasonably constant only after the oxides have grown to about 30 μm in thickness.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: For the high flux condition, the eventual uptake attained is about 80% of the theoretical compared to about 40% at the lower fluxes.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: For the high flux condition, the eventual uptake attained is about 80% of the theoretical compared to about 40% at the lower fluxes.

evidence_span: the percentage uptake is no greater than 5% even for high flux tubes after close to 10 full power years of operation.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: Deuterium pickup in garter springs can be minimized by ensuring that sufficient oxidant is present in the annulus gas to maintain a normal oxide film on these springs.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: uniform oxide growth rate of $0 . 1 \ \mu \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { d } \mathrm { a } )$ for Zircaloy-2 in a BWR (oxidizing) environment

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: Uniform oxide growth rates of $\sim 0 . 1$ to $0 . 2 \ \mu \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { d a y }$ are typical of oxidation rates for Zircaloy in pressurized water containing large amounts of dissolved oxygen.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: In PWRs, which operate with an excess of dissolved hydrogen, the growth rates are typically two orders of magnitude lower.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: uniform oxide growth rates in BWRs are less than 0.1 to $0 . 2 \ \mu \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { d a y }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: Under these conditions uniform oxide growth rates are about ten times less than that observed in oxygenated, pressurized water.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: corrosion and deuteriding accelerated with time once the oxide corrosion films exceeded a critical thickness of 15 to $2 0 \mu \mathbf { m }$

evidence_span: observed irradiation enhancement of corrosion at about $5 \mu \mathrm { { m } }$ oxide thickness
